Daniel, the growth in the number of species can be related to a number of=
 factors.  It does not necessarily indicate a problem with the NEAT code it=
self; more likely it reflects something about the system parameters used in=
 the particular experiment.  For example, if the compatibility threshold C_=
t is too low, it will encourage having many species.  The coefficients of c=
ompatibility (c1,c2,c3) also can have an affect on how whether individuals =
are considered compatible (i.e. in the same species).

The compatibility th=
reshold can be difficult to decide, so many version of NEAT shift it dynami=
cally to try to maintain a target number of species.  For example, if you w=
ant an equilibrium of 10 species but you have 15, then C_t should be raised=
 to make species more inclusive.  Conversely, if you have 5 species, C_t sh=
ould be lowered to make species more strict.  C_t can be raised or lowered =
by an increment at each generation.  That way the system will always be cha=
sing the desired target state, though it will not necessarily always hit it=
 perfectly.

Growth in species may also reflect too much structural mutatio=
n.  For example, if the probably of adding a node or connection is very hig=
h, then new species will proliferate so fast that NEAT cannot keep up (i.e.=
 the new species won't have time to optimize before they in turn start spaw=
ning new species).  So turning down mutation can also help with this kind o=
f species explosion.

The dropoff_age is a way to penalize stagnation.  It =
does not kill of species after e.g. 50 generations;  rather, it kills the s=
pecies off after 50 generations of *stagnation*, which means lack of improv=
ement in maximum fitness.  The idea is, if a species has not improved in a =
long time, then the investment that it represents in CPU resources may not =
be worth it, so it can be caused to die out by massively penalizing it.  Of=
 course, using this technique is optional and up to the experimenter.

ken
